div.l: And som tyme led with revel to Newgate
But atte last his mastre hym be thoght
Oppon a day when he his papir soght
Oppon a ꝓproverb that seith this same word
Wel bet is rotyn̄ Appil out of hord
Than that he rotyn̄ al the remnaunte
So farith it be ariotus ʆseruaunte
Hit is ful las harm̄ to lete hym̄ pase
Than he shuld al the ʆseruᵃauntes in þe plase
Ther̉e for his mastir ȝaf hym a quetaunce
And bad hym go with a sory myschaunce
And thus this Ioly Prentise had his leve
Nowe let hym ryot al the nyght or leve
And for ther̉e is no thefe with outyn̄ look
That helpith hym̄ to wastyn̄ or to sowk
Of þat he bribe can̄ or borowe may
Anon̄ he sellith his bed and his aray
Vn to a Compere of his own̄ sort
That lovid dise ryot and disport
And had a wyfe that he held for contenᵃaunce
A Shopp̄e and swyvid for her sustenᵃaunce
¶ Here endith the Cooke his tale
And here begynnyth the man of lawe his prolog
Our hoost sawe wele be þe bright son
The ark of his artificial day had I ron
The ferth part and half an hour͗e ⁊and more
Al thogh he were nat deppest stert in lore
He wist it was the xviij day
Of Apprill that is the messenger͗e to may
And sawe wel that þe shadowe of every tre
Was in lengith as the same quantite
That was the body erect that causid it
And þ̉erfor be the shadowe he toke his wit
That Phebus wich th shone so clere and bright
Degreis was xlv clombyn on hight
And therfor þat day was in latitude
